One of the benefits of using a rollup is the 1-2 second transaction confirmation time.

But how are rollups able to do this? Blockchain voodoo magic or some false sense of security?

Explaining the lifecycle of a rollup transaction ðŸ§µ: https://t.co/gbEuJUoT6e

A few things to note:

1. Due to the single-sequencer setup of rollups today, transactions are instantly confirmed and speculatively finalised on rollup block inclusion. There are no other block producers required to validate/confirm.

2. Hard finality(Stage 3 finality) should only be considered after the dispute period has passed, if no L1 rollbacks have occured prior to it i.e. finality stages 1 and 2. https://twitter.com/thepizzaknight_/status/1642584626366410752?s=46&t=GxyN7qBovxAqEoJW-dTZ8Q

3. The withdrawal of funds process does affect the L2 state and has its respective transaction lifecycle, usually overseen by dedicated opcodes and precompiles.

1) It's not instant, but it's quite fast - OP can take up to 2 seconds to confirm a txn. Other systems may allow for some MEV backrunning as well which adds further latency.

2) Again, the dispute period does not affect L2 state. Withdrawals are a way of convincing the L1 of the current L2 state, there is no way for a dispute to change L2 state.

@rauljordaneth made a great post on this yesterday: https://twitter.com/rauljordaneth/status/1703864326665241021.

The arbitrum docs further go into finality at each step: https://docs.arbitrum.io/tx-lifecycle - "nothing that can happen in phase 4 has any effect on the L1-level finality we've already locked in at phase 3".

I also recommend watching this talk from @kelvinfichter: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NKQz9jU0ftg.
